header.title: MAGICK OF EWAZ
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire Tradition, Demonic Magic

central_thesis: The 'Magick of Ewaz' presents a complete, ancient system of magick communicated by the demon Ewaz, enabling the practitioner to conjure and control powerful 'monsters of magick' from the infernal regions to grant wishes and achieve desired outcomes. It emphasizes strict adherence to rituals, the use of talismans, and personal fortitude to harness these dangerous forces.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the grimoire as a complete system of ancient magick from the demon Ewaz, warning of its wild and untamed power. It stresses extreme caution, secrecy, and strict adherence to instructions. The author describes strange sounds during writing and promises to reveal means to conjure and control these 'monsters of magick' using a 'Magick Key' and 'Concentration Armor'.

This part details the nature of the 'Devils Infernal Army' as ancient, transparent beings. It warns that misapplication can be disastrous, emphasizing that there's no definite defense or trapping procedure for these entities. It advises rapid learning and careful study, linking the practice to a dangerous 'light of day' evocation of 'hideous twisted forms.' The author also introduces the concept of Talismans and Charms, with further details in Part II.

This section explains that the provided magick, when drawn exactly, is charged with power. It introduces the 'Magick Key' as the means to open the 'evil gate leading to the dark depths of the infernal regions of Hell.' It stresses that the practitioner must learn the 'offer path,' conjure monsters to regain 'lost ancient magick,' and prepare for a 'horror' of screams and inhuman presences. It also advises wearing a black hooded robe as black is respected by demons.

This part reveals the 'Magick Key' for opening the gate. It provides specific instructions for the 'Conjuration,' stating it must be recited at midnight on a full moon in a deserted graveyard, while wearing a black robe and using a black candle. It then introduces the creation of 'Magick Talisman' symbols, to be written in the practitioner's blood under the same ritualistic conditions, emphasizing their unique and demon-directing nature. A general talismanic symbol is provided, and a severe warning is given about touching others with a charged talisman.
This section presents an illustration of a 'Commanding Soldier Demon,' visually representing the type of entity practitioners might encounter or command within the system.

structure_content.chapter_title: Conclusion To Part I Of Magick Of Morga
structure_content.summary: This short concluding note for Part I states that the author has provided the 'Magick Key' and 'armor' (wisdom). It ends with a 'Publishers Note' strongly advising against using the book, asserting it is 'far from complete' and 'for information purposes only,' highlighting its dangerous nature.

Part II begins with Robert Morga giving further teachings on making and using magick talismans, which he asserts is the 'highest magick.' He explains that talismans work via ancient demons and can be practiced secretly anytime. Morga emphasizes that this power comes from God to control demons, warns against profaning prayers, and instructs not to fear. He defines 'white' vs. 'black' magick as simply the use for good or bad intentions, stressing that a true magician seeks to get their wish from the demon. He reiterates the importance of patience, belief, and recognizing signs from the demons. The book is presented as a 'true story' and a dangerous, ancient wisdom passed down through his experience, not for the 'unenlightened'.

This section provides practical instructions for constructing talismans. They must be made from fresh white paper, with symbols drawn using black ink (or blood as previously stated) and cut out. It explicitly warns against changing the symbology to avoid 'occult guards' causing bad luck or internal destruction. It also provides 'The Magick Prayer' to be recited 'thrice at least' or repeatedly on the Sabbath, holding the talismans, to gain power over demons and command them to grant wishes.

This segment details how the talismans, once practiced as described, are charged 'supernaturally with great energy' by the demon when carried secretly on the person. It offers specific talisman designs: an 'Apple' symbol for attracting love, which should be touched to the beloved or their photograph/signature, and an 'S' symbol containing coins for attracting money, to be placed in a purse or wallet.

This section explains that the demons of Hell, under the Devil, are wish-granters and can become slaves to the practitioner's will upon appearance. It instructs on charging them by repeating 'MAGICK WORDS' (MASTER, I HEAR AND OBEY !! I WILL GRANT YOUR WISHES !!). It also details how to make pacts, signing with one's blood. The 'Demonic Worship' ritual involves honoring these monsters with sacrifice (one's own blood), kneeling before a statue or image of the demon (gargoyles recommended), stating 'I WORSHIP THEE Demon, SERVE ME!!' and 'I OFFER TO THEE DemoN, THIS SACRAFICE OF MY OWN BLOOD. SERVE ME!!', and rubbing blood on the demon's image or true form.

key_concepts.definition: The primary demon, described as 'wild and untamed,' who communicated this 'complete system of ancient magick' to Robert Morga. Ewaz is the source of the grimoire's power and instructions.

The entities to be conjured and controlled; transparent beings of an 'ancient race' that manifest as 'hideous twisted forms' when brought to light. They are powerful, dangerous, and can appear as an 'army'.
The specific conjuration and ritualistic framework required to open the 'evil gate' and summon the demons. This includes precise timing, location, attire, and spoken words.

Symbols drawn on white paper, ideally in the practitioner's own blood, under specific ritual conditions. These talismans are intended to represent a desired wish (e.g., love, money) and, once charged by the demon, empower the spell when carried.

A form of mental fortification or inner strength that the practitioner must develop to control the summoned demons and prevent being overwhelmed or destroyed by their power. It is crucial for survival and command.

A specific prayer directed to 'God' to grant power over demons, allowing the practitioner to command them to fulfill wishes. It is recited repeatedly, especially on the Sabbath, while holding the talismans.

Rituals involving revering the demons through verbal declarations of worship and offerings of the practitioner's own blood. This can be done before a demon's image or true form and is intended to gain their service.
Formal agreements made between the practitioner and the demons, signed with the practitioner's blood, to compel the demons to grant specific wishes. This signifies a binding commitment and command.

practical_system.description: The 'Magick of Ewaz' system is a direct, perilous form of demonic conjuration and control, purportedly communicated by the demon Ewaz. It involves summoning 'monsters of magick' to grant wishes through a structured combination of ritual timing, location, personal sacrifice (blood), and the creation of specialized talismans. Success mandates absolute adherence to Morga's instructions and the development of 'Concentration Armor' for self-protection and command. The system progresses from general conjuration to specific talismanic workings and culminates in rituals of demonic worship and blood-signed pacts, emphasizing the practitioner's will and desire for immediate results.
tools: Practitioner's own Blood (for talismans and pacts)
Stone Statue or Image of the Demon (e.g., gargoyle)
Specific Magick Talismans (e.g., Apple symbol for love, S-with-coins symbol for money)

critical_analysis.relevance: The 'Magick of Ewaz' contributes to modern grimoire literature by presenting a self-proclaimed 'ancient' system of demonolatry and practical magick. It deviates from classical grimoires by asserting direct communication with a named, unique demon, Ewaz, as the source of its teachings, rather than relying on established hierarchies or traditional kabbalistic frameworks. Its focus on personal blood sacrifice, direct command over 'monsters of magick,' and talismans for specific, mundane desires positions it within the tradition of pragmatic, results-oriented folk magic, albeit with a dark esoteric veneer. The explicit warnings throughout the text, coupled with the publisher's disclaimer, add a layer of mystique and danger, appealing to those seeking transgressive or 'forbidden' magical knowledge. It can be seen as an example of a modern, syncretic approach attempting to ground new demonic entities within an older magical paradigm.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is experienced practitioners of dark or infernal magic, particularly those interested in grimoire traditions, demonolatry, and direct command over spiritual entities. The author explicitly states it is 'not for beginners' and emphasizes 'use at own risk,' suggesting a readership already familiar with occult concepts and willing to engage with potentially hazardous, high-stakes magical practices. The book's dire warnings and the 'Publishers Note' advising against its use further indicate it is aimed at those who are drawn to extreme and transgressive forms of occultism, despite or because of the perceived danger. It is for those seeking personal power and material outcomes through direct manipulation of infernal forces.
